bestBHT.bht: The life of Jesus as a priest is established as endless or indissoluble, emphasizing His role for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This truth is witnessed in Scripture, specifically in Psalms 110:4. The distinction between Jesus and the rest of Levi is the perpetual nature of His priesthood, not bound by time. The eternal priesthood of Christ is definitively confirmed, either through the words of David or the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, attesting to its everlasting significance.

Henry Alford: Proof of the last clause from Scripture.
The stress of the citation is on for ever.
Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Proving His life to be 'endless' or indissoluble."
He is testified of, that Thou art.
Albert Barnes: That this is the true account of it is proved by the testimony of God himself, that he was to be a priest for ever.
This is the true account of it.
He was to be a priest for ever.
John Calvin: He then shows that Christ differs from the whole race of Levi, because he is made a priest for ever.
It must yet be also observed, that 'forever' is applied to the ancient sacrifices, not with regard to the external ceremony, but on account of their mystical signification.
Now when Christ is come, and a perpetual priesthood is given to him, we can find no end to his age, so that it cannot terminate after a certain period of time.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is witnessed (μαρτυρειτα). Present passive indicative of μαρτυρεω. The author aptly quotes again Psalms 110:4.
John Gill: For he testifieth...thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec."
That is, either David, the penman of the psalm, or rather the Holy Ghost, the enditer of it, or God in the Scripture.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse states that the life of Jesus as a priest is endless or indissoluble, emphasizing that He is a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This truth is supported by the testimony in Scripture, specifically Psalms 110:4, where it is witnessed that He is a priest forever. This distinction sets Jesus apart from the entire line of Levi, as He possesses a perpetual priesthood that cannot be terminated by time. Thus, the eternal priesthood of Christ is established, not only through the words of David, but also by the Holy Spirit, who inspired the Scripture.

The never-ending nature of Jesus' priesthood is emphasized, as He is declared to be a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This truth is firmly rooted in Scripture, specifically in Psalms 110:4 where it is testified that Jesus is a priest for eternity. His priesthood distinguishes Him from the entire lineage of Levi, as it is perpetual and cannot be terminated by time. The testimony in the psalm, written either by David or by the Holy Spirit, confirms the eternal nature of Christ's priesthood as stated in Hebrews 7:17.

The significance lies in the eternal nature of Jesus' priesthood, as indicated by the phrase Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This truth is firmly established through the testimony of Scripture, particularly Psalms 110:4, which emphasizes that Jesus' priesthood is endless and indissoluble. His priesthood is distinct from the line of Levi, as it is perpetual and transcends time. This profound declaration, whether uttered by David or inspired by the Holy Spirit, solidifies the irrevocable nature of Christ's priesthood.

The life of Jesus as a priest is established as endless or indissoluble, emphasizing His role for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This truth is witnessed in Scripture, specifically in Psalms 110:4. The distinction between Jesus and the rest of Levi is the perpetual nature of His priesthood, not bound by time. The eternal priesthood of Christ is definitively confirmed, either through the words of David or the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, attesting to its everlasting significance.

The foundational truth proclaimed in Scripture is the everlasting and indissoluble priesthood of Jesus, ordained for ever after the order of Melchisedec. This eternal priesthood is confirmed in Psalms 110:4, highlighting its perpetual nature. The distinctive quality of Christ's priesthood sets Him apart from the entire lineage of Levi, as it transcends time. The testimony of the psalm, attributed to either David or the Holy Spirit, solidifies the irrevocable and timeless priesthood of Jesus Christ.
